repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body: The spec says that clients specifying this capability also guarantee to gracefully handle fold kinds which are *not* in this set, which is the case for Neovim I believe. Looking through the code, seems like the only place that we "enforce" a kind to be in this set is through type annotations.

comment_data.body: Might be useful to log when we receive an unknown fold kind.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -48,7 +55,8 @@ local function renew(bufnr)
         row_text[start_row] = range.collapsedText
 
         local kind = range.kind
-        if kind then
+        -- Ignore unsupported fold kinds.

comment_data.body: Let's use `info` as we do with unknown diagnostic tags: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/492ea28612b2e47e187d6a37f582267655ba79fe/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/diagnostic.lua#L78
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -49,9 +56,14 @@ local function renew(bufnr)
 
         local kind = range.kind
         if kind then
-          local kinds = row_kinds[start_row] or {}
-          kinds[kind] = true
-          row_kinds[start_row] = kinds
+          -- Ignore unsupported fold kinds.
+          if supported_fold_kinds[kind] then
+            local kinds = row_kinds[start_row] or {}
+            kinds[kind] = true
+            row_kinds[start_row] = kinds
+          else
+            log.warn(('Received unsupported fold kind: "%s"'):format(kind))

comment_data.body: Ah, thanks that makes more sense👍
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -49,9 +56,14 @@ local function renew(bufnr)
 
         local kind = range.kind
         if kind then
-          local kinds = row_kinds[start_row] or {}
-          kinds[kind] = true
-          row_kinds[start_row] = kinds
+          -- Ignore unsupported fold kinds.
+          if supported_fold_kinds[kind] then
+            local kinds = row_kinds[start_row] or {}
+            kinds[kind] = true
+            row_kinds[start_row] = kinds
+          else
+            log.warn(('Received unsupported fold kind: "%s"'):format(kind))

comment_regular_data.body: If it doesn't exist already, can we add a test that shows that we do gracefully handle kinds that aren't listed here?

LGTM. However, based on the next sentence in the documentation:

>  and falls back to a default value when unknown.

I believe our current mechanism doesn’t set it to a default value, but rather keeps unknown types as they are. If needed, we could set them to `region`, with the potential advantage (or possibly disadvantage) that `vim.lsp.foldclose('region')` would also apply to these kinds.
Looks like VSCode treats unsupported fold kinds as if they were `undefined`/not passed in at all. Maybe we can copy that?

> Looks like VSCode treats unsupported fold kinds as if they were `undefined`/not passed in at all.


Sounds more reasonable. Sometimes I feel that some of the odd definitions in the LSP might just be describing how vscode does things, so perhaps the best way to implement LSP is to imitate vscode :P

> > Looks like VSCode treats unsupported fold kinds as if they were `undefined`/not passed in at all.
> 
> Sounds more reasonable. Sometimes I feel that some of the odd definitions in the LSP might just be describing how vscode does things, so perhaps the best way to implement LSP is to imitate vscode :P

VS Code should follow its own spec though. In case of ambiguities we should create an issue in the LSP repo and ask them to be specific.

In this case, what exists in the spec is an *undefined* value, not an *ambiguous* one — that is, the spec doesn’t specify what the “default value” should be. I believe it’s normal for specs to leave certain things undefined, just like most specifications do. More importantly, when implementing the spec, the server should not assume any particular default value or rely on such undefined behavior, so this should not affect actual functionality. I think we just need to determine the default value on a case-by-case basis.

PS: My later sarcasm was not implying that vscode doesn't need to follow the spec, but that it can make the spec describe its own behavior, in which case it is still complying with the spec. One example I found is https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-languageserver-node/issues/684.

@ofseed agreed. To be clear, I've also fallen victim to the thought of "let's just copy what VS Code does" when the LSP spec leaves details "as an exercise for the reader". Not sure if this is always the best scenario to be in though.
is this blocked on tests or can we merge it

> is this blocked on tests or can we merge it

We should address @ofseed's remarks about falling back to something with unknown fold kinds.
Folds with unsupported kind now have their `kind` field ignored :+1:

title: fix(lsp): advertise supported fold kinds
